question:
The oracle warns us that we we have left our pot unwatched, and our food now burns.'
This statement in The Gods Are Not To Blame refers to
options: the crime of incest committed by King Odewale

question: '...the toad likes water but not when the water is boiling'. King Odewale in the Gods Are Not To Blame uses this proverb to explain why he
options: he exiled himself from the home of his supposed parents.
no longer likes the land of Kutuje.

question:
Baba Fakunle: How much did he give you boy?
Boy: Ten cowries, Baba.
Baba Fakunle: Hand him back nine.
The order to return nine cowries was given by Baba Fakunle because he
options: wanted to spit the King by taking only one cowrie
felt insulted that he was given only ten cowries
did not want to meddle with leprous monry given with bloody hands
wanted to emphasize that the messanger of Olodumare takes only one cowrie.

question:
''When the frog in front falls in a pit, others behind takes caution... When crocodiles eat their own eggs, what will they will they not do to the flesh of a frog?''
In the context of The Gods Are Not To Blame, the person who made this statement is alleging that king Adetusa
options: died falling in to a pit
fell victim to man eating crocodiles
was killed by the people of Kutuje
was killed by the Ijekun people.

question: Odewale shifts the blame for his tragedy from the gods to himself and claims that his tragedy is a result of his own weakness. The weakness he claims is love of
The treatment meted out to Cinna the poet in Julius Caesar shows
options: that roman soldiers despised poets generally
Shakespeare's use of mistaken identity for comic effect in the play
the spontaneous reaction of the plebians after assassination of Caesar.

question: The specific case cited by Antony in his funeral oration to show that Caesar was not as ambitious as Brutus made him out to be, was that Caesar had
options: refused to take ransom after his victory
thrice refused the crown during theb feast of Luperical
been a friend of the senators.

question: Shakespeare based the story of Julius Caesar on

'...He would be crown'd.
How that may change his nature, there's the question
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder.
And that craves wary walking...'
According to this passage, the crowning of Julius Caesar is
options: bound to change Caesar's nature for the better
bound to promote the breeding of adders
something to be approached with great caution

question: In Julius Caesar, one occasion when the misunderstanding of the ordinary people of Rome caused a big problem was
options: at the capitol when Caesar was given a crown
at the capitol when Brutus and Antony addressed the Romans
at the battlefield when Brutus attacked the army of octavius
in the streets of Rome when Cinna the poet was killed.

question: In Mission To Kala, Medza regarded himself as a professional failure because he
options: he did not seem to have any particular plans forn his life
had a bad reputation at college as a person with bad manners
failed to bring back Niam's wife

question: Medza's Mission To Kala was important mainly because it
options: helped him to make acquaintance with his relations in Kala
gave him the glory of bringing back Niam's wife
made him discover the realities of the condition of colonized people.

question: The attitude of the young men of Kala towards their chief can be described as

'Why the hell can't some of you caught him for me
Are you going to let a boy make a public laughing stock of his own father?
The speaker of these words is the father of

From Madza's behavior after his return to Kala
it can be deduced that the most important lesson he learned from his sojourn in Kala is that
options: the secret of happiness is to be found among unsophisticated Africans
every man is free to set his own goals and chart his own course in life
formal education is the ideal way to true wisdom
it is highly rewarding to abide scrupulously by the mores of one's own community.

question: The protagonist of Charles Dicken's Great Expectations is
The effect of Pip's association with the inmates of Satis house was made to make him
options: realize that he was an orphan
despair of even being a gentle man
aspire to improve his education and make himself less common

question: Joe Gargery is important in Great Expectations mainly because he
options: is used as a foil to Pip
provides the comedy in the story
helped to bring Pip up by hand
nursed Pip when he was sick in London.

question: When Mr. Jagger''s told Joe Gargery to ''bear in mind, that Brag is a good dog, but Holdfast is a better'', what he meant was that
options: Holdfast was a better dog when compared to Brag
it was better to hold fast on one''s beliefs than to brag about them
a faithful, steadfast dog was better than a dog that gives one cause to bragof its beauty
Joe Gargery should keep his mouth shut.

question: In Great Expectations, Pip's reaction to the news that his fortune had been bestowed on him by Magwitch was
The dominant mood in J.P. Clark's 'Night Rain' is that of
The impression created of the rain in J.P. Clark's 'Night Rain' is that of
options: an invading but paradoxically welcome force

question: From the poem itself, it is easy to tell that J.P. Clark's Abiku' is set in
options: a hut in a riverine village
a modern city by the sea
the only mansion in the village.

question: The tone of Wole Soyinka's 'Abiku is
Which of the following statement is NOT true of the two 'Abiku' poems by J.P Clark and Wole Soyinka?
options: in each of the two poems, the voice of the Abiku is heard
while the tone of Clark's poem is conciliatory, that of Soyinka is defiant
it would appear that making body marks on the two Abiku has not served the customary purpose of stopping them from coming again
as the two poet portray them, Clark's Abiku can choose to stay or not to stay, but Soyinka's Abiku cannot.

question: In the poem 'The Vultures', David Diop suggests that the Christians missionaries were agents of

'The Vultures built in the shadow of their talons
The blood-stained monument of tutelage.'
The image used in the above lines associates the civilizing missions with
Much of the poetic effect of Birago Diop's 'Viaticum' is gained by the poet's use of

The gurgling drums
Echo the stars
The forest howls
And between the tress
The dark sun appears.
The dominant figure of speech in the above lines from Lenrie Peter's 'We Have Come Home' is
The theme of Gabriel Okara's 'piano and Drums' is usually summed up in the phrase

Tunde's long and vigorous speech was followed by a deafening silence.
The phrase deafening silence is used as a figure of speech called

'No; This my hand will rather
The multitudinous seas incarnadine
Making the green and red .'
In the above lines the figure of speech used is

When the speech is written so as to be understood in one way by a certain character, while the audience or another character understands it to have some secret and special meaning, the literary device used in this context is called
The epilogue in a play refers to the
Which of the following is NOT a form of poetic expression
Reversal of fortune as used in the criticism of a literary work describes the
options: rise to fame of the central character
success of the hero or heroine
sudden change in the fate of the central character.

question: Which of the following could be said to be a permanent feature of a poem?
Which of the following terms is exclusive to drama?
The literary device which uses ridicule to correct social ills is known as
A poem of mourning and dedicated written on the death of an individual is called
A poem written on a grand theme, in an appropriately grand style, dealing with heroic figures is called
Characterization in a novel means the
options: list of characters featuring in it
mode of presenting the fictional individuals
resolution of the conflict between the characters.

question:
'' It was dawn, and the windows were dark except for the Workmen cafes. The sky was like a avast flat wall of cobalt, with roofs and spires of black paper pasted upon it. Drowsy men were sweeping the pavements with ten-foot brooms, and ragged families picking over the dustbins. Workmen and girls with piece of chocolate in one hand and bread in the other were pouring into the railway station.'
The picture presented above is one of

Much madness is divinest sense
To a discerning eye;
Much sense is starkest madness.
'This the majority
In this, as all, prevails.
Assent, and you are sane;
Demur,-you're straightway dangerous,
And handled with a chain.
This poem reflects the

The bustle in a house
The morning after death
Is solemnest of industries
Enacted upon earth-
The sweeping up the heart
And putting love away
We shall not want to use again
Until eternity.
The predominant mood of this poem is best captured by the words

'Chini was breathing with a love ripeness in her eye. She was elegant, sophistication, and Nigerian costume with charm. her every movement stimulated a flow of poetry from Francois and an ebb of embarrassment from her. she called him "My mad French lover".'
The tone of this passage is

'Nature sent him into the world strong and lusty, in a thriving condition, wearing his own hair on his head the proper branches of this reasoning vegetable, until the axe of intemperance has lopped off his green boughs, and left him a withered trunk...'
In this passage, axe of intemperance means

From that moment on he began to notice what was happening in town, but in a very inexact way, for Father Anthony Isabel, in part because of his age and in part also because he swore he had seen the devil on three occasions (something which seem to the town just a bit out of place), was considered by his parishioners as a good man, peaceful and obliging, but with his head habitually in the clouds.
The phrase, something which seemed to the town just a bit out of place, is an example of
